thread.title: Hundreds unite for Sophia Bartlow’s memorial paddle out in Huntington Beach
thread.title_full: Hundreds unite for Sophia Bartlow’s memorial paddle out in Huntington Beach

author: SUP Magazine
title: Hundreds unite for Sophia Bartlow’s memorial paddle out in Huntington Beach
text:
Hundreds unite for Sophia Bartlow’s memorial paddle out in Huntington Beach 
  SUP Magazine 
Editor’s note: This story was originally written by our friends at SUPthemag.com . Check out their site for more SUP news and information. 
Hundreds of surfers, paddlers and friends paddled out at Huntington Beach Pier this past Saturday to celebrate the life of professional paddler and surfer Sophia Tiaré Bartlow. 
The ceremony was draped in Hawaiian culture as Bartlow and her family were deeply ingrained in the island community. Photo: Courtesy of Mike Muir The 25-year-old tragically passed away two weeks ago in a car crash near Waialua, on Oahu, Hawaii. 
RELATED: SUP athlete Sophia Tiare Bartlow dies in car crash 
She was a beloved member of the ocean sports community and was well-known for her contagious positivity and hard-charging attitude on the water. 
The crowd was even thicker than usual at the Huntington Beach Pier before the paddle out. Photo: Courtesy of Mike Muir The crowd at Bartlow’s memorial was a testament to her undeniable popularity, with over a thousand people coming out to pay tribute. 
In a particularly touching moment, people formed three circles in the water and began chanting Bartlow’s mantra — Love, Shine, Glow! — while a lifeguard boat fired a cannon shot in her honor. 
Following the paddle out, family and friends embraced and shared memories, including a heartfelt remembrance by fellow paddler and close friend, Candice Appleby. Here are a few more scenes from the emotional ceremony. The community in mourning came together by the hundreds. Photo: Courtesy of Mike Muir Bartlow’s mother, surrounded by love. Photo: Courtesy of Mike Muir Group paddle outs are a tradition among watermen and women to honor lost lives in their community. The showing for Bartlow’s memorial was touching. Photo: Courtesy of Mike Muir
